detailed_profile.name: Scott Blackburn
detailed_profile.city: Washington, District of Columbia, United States
detailed_profile.position: Senior Partner, McKinsey & Company
detailed_profile.about: I am a Senior Partner at McKinsey & Company focusing on US Public Sector - particularly defense & security, health care, technology, large-scale transformation, and capability building. I am passionate about Veterans issues through helping non-profits support Veterans and making McKinsey more Veteran-friendly. I returned to McKinsey in 2018 after leading transformation efforts at the Department of Veterans Affairs, the US federal government's 2nd largest agency, from 2014-2018 serving in a variety of roles to include Chief Transformation Officer, Interim Deputy Secretary (COO) and Chief Information Officer. During my tenure at VA, Veteran trust in VA improved from 47% to now >80% as VA focused on customer experience, improving access and timeliness of care and services, improving efficiency/effectiveness of operations, modernizing through technology (to include digital experience, Electronic Health Records, and technology infrastructure), improving the employee experience, and expanding strategic partnerships (with private sector, non-profits, Department of Defense, states, other government agencies and Veteran Service Organizations). I am a proud US Army Veteran and a dedicated advocate for our nation‚Äôs Veterans. I am a Scituate Massachusetts native, a sports fanatic (Boston, Cleveland and all things football), and father of 3 amazing children (2 hockey goalies and an Ice Dancer).

volunteer_experience.info: Founded in 2012 by three combat Veterans, VETSports aims to set the standard for how to improve Veterans‚Äô physical, mental, and emotional health through sports, physical activity, and community involvement. volunteer_experience.info: The Concussion Legacy Foundation is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization based in the United States with chapters in Australia, Canada and the United Kingdom. It was founded by Robert Cantu, MD, and Chris Nowinski, PhD to support athletes, veterans and all affected by concussions and CTE, to promote smarter sports and safer athletes through education and innovation, and End CTE through prevention and research. CLF is a proud supporter of and collaborator with the Boston University CTE Center.

publications.title: Moving teams from campaign to transition: Five things to get right
publications.subtitle: McKinsey.com
publications.description: The brief period between election and inauguration is a high-stakes sprint to prepare to govern. The effectiveness of this period hinges on shifting rapidly from campaigning to planning the transition‚Äîtwo efforts with very different objectives and skill sets. A campaign is laser focused on victory and rewards the skills and culture that maximize that focus. Following the election, a significantly expanded team must pivot hard to setting up the infrastructure required to govern and bring together multiple pre-election efforts‚Äîa process-heavy endeavor that can feel quite different from a campaign. There are five crucial elements to get right in integrating the expanded post-election transition team.

detailed_profile.name: Vijay Sarathy
detailed_profile.position: Partner, McKinsey & Company. Supporting senior chemical executives gain conviction behind their most strategic decisions
detailed_profile.about: Born and raised in New Delhi, I studied chemical engineering and business in India before launching a 35+ year career that has taken me all over the world. For the past ~25+ years, I have served as an advisor to senior executives in the global chemicals industry. Prior to that I was an executive at chemical companies in India and Indonesia for close to a decade in marketing, procurement and strategy roles. As a strategy consultant, my goal is to guide my clients during their most critical moments, and to help them gain conviction behind the decisions that they need to make to be successful. I currently live in Boston and travel where my work leads me. Specialties: Corporate and Business Unit Strategy, Mergers and Acquisitions, Commercial Excellence and Organizational Culture

recommendations: Gene Cornfield ‚ÄúVijay is among the senior leaders with whom I most enjoy partnering. Consulting at its best is a team sport in which the best outcomes -- both for the team and for clients -- result from individual players who are at the top of their game, and who are able to make one another better. That's the kind of player/coach Vijay is. What has struck me most -- beyond the credibility Vijay has established as a leading expert in the chemicals industry -- is the trust CEOs and other C-level executives have in him. I know from my own career experience that such a high level of trust must be earned, and built over many years. When we achieve a certain point and level in our careers, finding mentors from whom we can learn and continue to grow professionally becomes more challenging. Vijay has been a mentor to me and many others -- his insightful video on how consulting must be bought from trusted advisors, and practical guidance on how people at all levels can become one, is a seminal asset that should be required for all client-facing people at Accenture. I'm grateful for the opportunities Vijay has provided me to share and to learn and for the example he sets.‚Äù

Ojas Wadivkar ‚ÄúVijay is the Chemicals Industry "CEO whisperer" with a strong ability to build and nurture his relations. This allows the firm access to have meaningful conversations with client executives. He is also a Chemicals Industry expert and provides insights to the team to tailor offerings to clients. Finally he is a positive force within the Chemicals community and a good mentor and team member across the consulting ranks.‚Äù

publications.title: Unlocking value from IoT connectivity: Six considerations for choosing a provider
publications.subtitle: McKinsey & Company
publications.description: Companies must take a more nuanced look at connectivity providers as the Internet of Things evolves.The Internet of Things (IoT) is growing rapidly, with 127 new devices connecting to the Internet every second. Although many new applications target consumers, including smart-home systems and connected cars, others help companies optimize operations ranging from manufacturing to customer segmentation. As IoT expands, companies‚Äô connectivity expenditures will rise by about 15 percent annually through 2022. To capture this growth, connectivity providers will extend their coverage and investigate innovative technologies, including low-power, wide-area networks (LPWANs).Such shifts could have major repercussions for companies that sell IoT devices or services. For many years, they relied on country leads to select connectivity providers, and the default choice was often the largest regional or local player. A few also asked systems integrators for provider recommendations, often with similar results. But as IoT becomes more important to the bottom line, companies must reassess their connectivity needs and make more nuanced decisions that consider global coverage, intelligent-switching capabilities, service delivery, pricing, security, and IoT expertise.

recommendations: Stephen Garratt ‚ÄúQuentin has always been way ahead of the curve when it comes to digital. When we founded Electric Ocean in Cape Town, together with Nick Wittenberg, it was one of the first digital agencies of it's kind in the world; and that is characteristic of Quentin. Working alongside Quentin in building and training a team of 35 web developers, client execs, planners and designers was formative and he also made it fun.‚Äù

Lance Larsen ‚ÄúQuentin's leadership in delivering highly valuable digital media experiences is now legend, so I won't belabor that at all. I wanted to recommend his passion... his ability to remain incredibly upbeat and positive even in the face of extreme hardship, and his ability to lead through positive example and by encouraging the heart of those in his midst. He is always paying keen attention to the needs of clients and others around him first, while also not losing sight of externally factors like markets, trends, innovation, and management techniques. He is one of the best people I have ever worked with, and consider the time we spent together at Razorfish one of the highlights of my career and an honor and privilege not soon forgotten.‚Äù

detailed_profile.name: Daniella Seiler
detailed_profile.position: Executive Editor at McKinsey & Company
detailed_profile.about: I am a versatile writer, editor, thought partner, and people and project manager who has spent more than a decade crafting data-driven stories about today's critical business and economic issues. I lead global teams of McKinsey leaders and experts to create distinctive thought leadership content on a diverse portfolio of topics. During my tenure at McKinsey, I have developed more than 150 survey questionnaires and 200 pieces of original content for publication, including articles (both digital and print), data-based interactives, interviews, videos, newsletters, and content for non-McKinsey channels. I'm also passionate about the great outdoors, good food, exercise, volunteering, racial and social justice, and Latin American literature.

detailed_profile.name: Cait Murphy
detailed_profile.city: New York, New York, United States
detailed_profile.position: Senior Editor at McKinsey & Company
detailed_profile.about: From speech-writing to writing and editing books to working with consultancies to turn research into something like English, I have an extensive editorial background. I know quite a bit about business, Asia, New York City, and economics; my knowledge of early 20th century baseball is embarrassingly profound (see link on left). Generally, I can get interested in almost anything, and am a quick study. I have a full-time job, but am interested in project work. In the last year, for example, I have edited one book on accounting standards in Japan, which was not the most fascinating topic, and another on the future of the solar industry, which was genuinely interesting. I also wrote a report for a private-equity group and a feature article for Inc. magazine.

My personal passions are leadership development and working with students and professionals to help them discover their own ambitions and career paths. I take a compassionate, curious, optimistic, and collaborative approach to working with people, using active listening to help each person discover their interests and aspirations, expand their skillsets, create connections, and to make informed decisions about their educational and professional journeys. basic_info.name: Wendy Stratman Miller
basic_info.search_snippet: I am the Chief People Officer for North America at McKinsey & Company, where I shape and manage the firm's People strategy, processes, and professional teams.

detailed_profile.name: Wendy Stratman Miller
detailed_profile.position: Partner, North American Chief People Officer, McKinsey & Company
detailed_profile.about: I am the Chief People Officer for North America at McKinsey & Company, where I shape and manage the firm's People strategy, processes, and professional teams. During my 20 years in numerous roles across McKinsey's People function, I have built and overseen an integrated team. This team has direct responsibility for recruiting, professional development, evaluations and reviews, learning, and human resources. I partner globally to design our firm's regional People strategy, shaping our employee value proposition and experience. This includes building a robust diversity and inclusion strategy and fostering a stronger culture of development. I am deeply committed to leveraging GenAI advancements within our organization, applying innovative solutions to enhance our approach to various HR initiatives including performance reviews. Every day, I am dedicated to building a remarkable firm that attracts, develops, excites, and retains exceptional people. Prior to my People roles, I was a McKinsey consultant serving clients on various strategic topics with a focus on marketing and sales in the consumer and retail industries. I have an MBA from Harvard Business School and a BS in Accounting from Miami University. I live in Atlanta, GA, with my husband Matt and our three children. Outside of work, I'm an active tennis player, runner, enthusiastic cook, and avid traveler.

detailed_profile.name: Marc Singer
detailed_profile.position: Senior Partner Emeritus at McKinsey & Company, Board Member, Advisor, and Investor
detailed_profile.about: I serve on several private company and not-for-profit boards, as an investor in several early stage companies, and as a coach to some of the many senior leaders that I've had the privilege to work with over the years. I am also a faculty member for McKinsey's Executive Transition Masterclass, a program for new CxOs, BU leaders, and equivalent that aims to help executives realize their and their organization's full potential in those key periods. As a Senior Partner in McKinsey & Company‚Äôs San Francisco office, I worked extensively with financial services, technology, telecommunications, retail and hospitality firms on an array of strategy, organization, operations, marketing, sales, and data and technology-enablement opportunities. For McKinsey, I played various roles in our firm's Growth Marketing & Sales Practice over the years. These included creating and leading the Digital Marketing Practice and leading the overall Practice for the Americas. I have deep expertise in applying data, analytics, and technology to drive more profitable customer experience management, customer loyalty and retention, consumer and shopper insights. I‚Äôve written numerous articles on the evolution of customer loyalty programs, e-commerce, marketing analytics, and other topics in publications such as the McKinsey Quarterly, Harvard Business Review, CRM Magazine, and Forbes. Additionally, I co-authored the book "Net Worth: Shaping Markets When Customers Make the Rules" with John Hagel.

recommendations: John Murabito ‚ÄúI felt like Kristen would be right for Cigna‚Äôs open CMO position the moment I met her. She has a great balance of successful line operating responsibility and transformational, growth focused CMO experience. Her humility and authenticity are attractive qualities for a senior leader and I was drawn to that and to her varied experience. Kristen joined Cigna during the first month of the global pandemic knowing only 10 of 75,000 employees. In her first six months, Kristen launched initiatives that directly impacted society ‚Äì including the Brave of Heart Fund. Over 18 months, she developed a highly diverse, high-performing team that digitally launched a breakthrough health services brand, Evernorth, representing a significant growth engine for the company. Kristen's leadership and experience are well suited for the challenges we must tackle in the world ahead.‚Äù

basic_info.name: Evelyn Kay - Business Analyst at McKinsey & Company
basic_info.search_snippet: Business Analyst at McKinsey & Company based out of the Chicago office. Graduated Summa Cum Laude from the University of Southern California in 2023.

detailed_profile.name: Evelyn Kay
detailed_profile.position: Business Analyst at McKinsey & Company | Industrial Engineer and Artist
detailed_profile.about: Business Analyst at McKinsey & Company based out of the Chicago office. Graduated Summa Cum Laude from the University of Southern California in 2023 with my M.S. in Product Development Engineering (Systems Track) through the Viterbi Progressive Degree Program. Graduated Magna Cum Laude in May 2022 with my B.S. in Industrial and Systems Engineering (Operations Track). Former Continuous Improvement Intern at Union Pacific Railroad and Manufacturing Engineering Intern at Northrop Grumman for the F/A-18 International Pursuits team. 2021 Co-President of the Helenes, USC's oldest service organization on campus, during our centennial year. I am an engineer and an artist pursuing a career that merges both and engages my creativity.

experience.title: Business Analyst (Operations)
experience.description: In my role as a Business Analyst at McKinsey & Company in Chicago, I consult on global transformations for Fortune 500 clients in the automotive, aerospace, and shipbuilding industries. I've developed multi-year strategies for automation technology implementation, upscaled supply chain capabilities through advanced Excel models, and analyzed client data to identify multi-million-dollar cost-saving opportunities. My work has been hands-on and implementation-focused, and I've led cross-national workshops across various operations functions both on the shop floor and in management teams. I strive for ownership in all of my work and manage standalone work streams with an entrepreneurial drive
experience.description_html: In my role as a Business Analyst at McKinsey & Company in Chicago, I consult on global transformations for Fortune 500 clients in the automotive, aerospace, and shipbuilding industries. I've developed multi-year strategies for automation technology implementation, upscaled supply chain capabilities through advanced Excel models, and analyzed client data to identify multi-million-dollar cost-saving opportunities. My work has been hands-on and implementation-focused, and I've led cross-national workshops across various operations functions both on the shop floor and in management teams. I strive for ownership in all of my work and manage standalone work streams with an entrepreneurial drive

experience.title: Continuous Improvement Intern
experience.description: Worked at Union Pacific Railroad as a Continuous Improvement Intern in the Supply Department on innovating new strategies for implementing Lean Manufacturing and Six Sigma practices across railroad field/office roles. Mentored, led, and problem solved with the UP Way. Led and organized CI team Audit Day. Worked to improve quality and reduce cycle times of UP Way Certification training program. Developed leadership skills, standardized work, and gained hands-on railroad experience through site visits. Certified in Advanced 8-Step Problem Solving and pursuing certification in the UP Way.Combined my artistic and creative skills with my engineering background to design new training materials and visual aids for field and office roles.
experience.description_html:
Worked at Union Pacific Railroad as a Continuous Improvement Intern in the Supply Department on innovating new strategies for implementing Lean Manufacturing and Six Sigma practices across railroad field/office roles. Mentored, led, and problem solved with the UP Way. Led and organized CI team Audit Day. Worked to improve quality and reduce cycle times of UP Way Certification training program.

Developed leadership skills, standardized work, and gained hands-on railroad experience through site visits. Certified in Advanced 8-Step Problem Solving and pursuing certification in the UP Way.

Combined my artistic and creative skills with my engineering background to design new training materials and visual aids for field and office roles.

experience.title: Manufacturing Engineering Intern for F/A-18 International Pursuits
experience.description: Returned to my position at Northrop Grumman for a Summer 2021 internship with the F/A-18 International Pursuits team. Completed a cross-functional Foreign Object Accountability project to investigate the root cause of FO escapes, eliminate future FO errors in the production of the F/A-18, and optimize paint operations for the aircraft. Drafted a manual of best practices to standardize these recommendations.Led a project proposed last summer to implement the creation of video work instructions for the production of the F/A-18. Worked across functions and utilized my film and photography creative expertise alongside my engineering knowledge. Finished a robust document guiding future teams through the necessary steps to continue the project past my internship, as well as to standardize these efforts. Continued my efforts from Summer 2020 to improve the Supplier Tooling Evaluation Data packages, wrote a new tutorial to standardize the updated process for creating these.
experience.description_html:
Returned to my position at Northrop Grumman for a Summer 2021 internship with the F/A-18 International Pursuits team. Completed a cross-functional Foreign Object Accountability project to investigate the root cause of FO escapes, eliminate future FO errors in the production of the F/A-18, and optimize paint operations for the aircraft. Drafted a manual of best practices to standardize these recommendations.

Led a project proposed last summer to implement the creation of video work instructions for the production of the F/A-18. Worked across functions and utilized my film and photography creative expertise alongside my engineering knowledge. Finished a robust document guiding future teams through the necessary steps to continue the project past my internship, as well as to standardize these efforts.

Continued my efforts from Summer 2020 to improve the Supplier Tooling Evaluation Data packages, wrote a new tutorial to standardize the updated process for creating these.

Contributed valuable work to the future of international defense in my Summer 2020 internship for the Northrop Grumman International Pursuits team. Consolidated workshare packages for foreign entities and gained exposure to assembly line and aerospace technology.

Developed an outstanding knowledge of F/A-18 production/technology, Lean Manufacturing strategy, supply chain work, project management, international contracts. Conducted a thorough program analysis and proposed an operations improvement plan to my team.

Standardized work by creating tutorials for technical data packages to implement Lean strategy within our team, cut down future work hours, and maintain efficiency.

detailed_profile.city: Washington, District of Columbia, United States
detailed_profile.position: Compliance Administrator at McKinsey & Company
detailed_profile.about: My name is Catherine Rogers Camphor. I am a young professional in the DC Metro area. My life has always revolved around one certain phrase: "We all need somebody to lean on". I always strive to make every day resemble this simple message. I enjoy helping people be their best and live up to their full potential. It is incorporated into every area of my life, both personally and professionally. I believe you leave a piece of yourself in everyone you meet in life so make sure it's a good piece. My goals professionally are to help people and to go to work every day doing what I love.

publications.title: 2017 Women in the Workplace
publications.subtitle: McKinsey & Company and LeanIn.org
publications.description: Women remain underrepresented at every level in corporate America, despite earning more college degrees than men for thirty years and counting. There is a pressing need to do more, and most organizations realize this: company commitment to gender diversity is at an all-time high for the third year in a row.Despite this commitment, progress continues to be too slow‚Äîand may even be stalling. One of the most powerful reasons for this is a simple one: we have blind spots when it comes to diversity, and we can‚Äôt solve problems that we don‚Äôt see or understand clearly.Women in the Workplace 2017 is a comprehensive study of the state of women in corporate America. This research is part of a long-term partnership between LeanIn.Org and McKinsey & Company to give organizations the information they need to promote women‚Äôs leadership and foster gender equality.

publications.title: The Strong Gray Line: War-time Reflections from the West Point Class of 2004
publications.subtitle: Rowman & Littlefield Publishers
publications.description: Contributing Author. To preserve the memory of their service during the tumultuous decade since their commissioning as Army officers, members of the West Point class of 2004 have written The Strong Gray Line. This class suffered the highest casualty rate since those that graduated during the Vietnam War. In this book, thirteen of their classmates who lost their lives fighting the Global War on Terror are profiled to help the reader gain an understanding of the bond forged between classmates during time at West Point, a bond that transcends the separation of death.In addition to the stirring profiles, thirteen personal essays detail some of the most brutal fighting of Operations Iraqi Freedom and Enduring Freedom in addition to the struggles endured by those on the home front. These stories range from visceral observations of combat to a wife‚Äôs anxious wait for her husband to return home. Holistically, these stories define an emotional spectrum that enables the reader to connect not only with the experience of the Class of 2004, but with every man and woman who served their country in a time of war.

basic_info.search_snippet: I am a Senior Partner with McKinsey & Company and lead our Global Health Insurance Practice and Center for US Healthcare Improvement.

detailed_profile.name: David G. Knott
detailed_profile.city: New York, New York, United States
detailed_profile.position: Senior Partner at McKinsey & Company
detailed_profile.about: I am a Senior Partner with McKinsey & Company and lead our Global Health Insurance Practice and Center for US Healthcare Improvement, as well as previously our Center for US Health System Reform. Over the past three decades, I have worked with many of the leading health insurers, providers, large employers, and health agencies. I counsel client CEOs, top teams, and Boards on both strategy development as well as transformation programs, including future operating model definition, organization re-design, capability building, cost restructuring, M&A integration, and Board restructuring. I am passionate about making high quality health care affordable for everyone in America, particularly the least well off, and led the launch of our Medicaid Practice. My publications have focused on growth opportunities in Medicaid, the impact of big data in health care, high performance provider networks, and US health care costs. I have served as a keynote speaker with over a hundred companies as well as industry forums including AHIP, BCBSA, National Governors Association, NIHCM, and Health Datapalooza. Within McKinsey, I am an enthusiastic advocate for advancing the careers of our women professionals. I have served as Global Dean of Inclusive Learning, faculty for our Women‚Äôs Pathway to Partner program, and built gender balanced teams to serve the clients I help advise. In recognition of my impact in helping our women colleagues realize their professional aspirations, I was chosen by McKinsey‚Äôs women Partners and Senior Partners to receive one of the Firm‚Äôs highest honors, the Lowell Bryan Award. Within the Firm, I have also helped Chair our Global Partner Review Committee and currently am a member of Echelon, a small group of Senior Partners selected by our Global Managing Partner to help introduce and scale new clients, as well as on McKinsey‚Äôs Special Initiative on CEO Counseling. Outside the Firm, I am a passionate supporter of the arts and serve on the Advisory Board of the New York Metropolitan Opera (underwrote The Enchanted Island) and Chair the Executive Committee of the Manhattan School of Music. My wife, Francoise Girard, and I also helped launch Maestro William Christie‚Äôs baroque opera festival with Les Arts Florissants and the Juilliard School. Prior to joining McKinsey, I completed a Ph.D. and Master's in Political Philosophy from Oxford University as well as a B.A. Honours degree in Canada from Queen's University. I live in Manhattan and Montreal.

recommendations: Satya Bhan ‚ÄúMailchimp has been my first deep dive into front end development. I started working with Sarah right from the start, iterating on designs, providing engineering feedback to streamline development. It has been such a joy to work with her. She has a keen eye for details and really listening and incorporating the feedback into her designs. I especially recall a meeting where we were brainstorming a UX experience and spitballing ideas and by the end of the meeting she already had a full blown figma design ready. I love how she can take abstract concepts we are discussing and bring them to life. I also really appreciate how proactive Sarah is about her communication. In case of any clarifications or ambiguity she is great at setting up quick meetings to resolve discussions and provide clearly labeled designs to the team. And she has an awesome fun bubbly personality. I've absolutely loved working with her :)‚Äù

Ricky Knight ‚ÄúI worked with Sarah at Mailchimp and she is an incredibly talented designer and a pleasure to work with. recommendations: LinkedIn User ‚ÄúOsato stands out as one of the most inspirational multimedia leaders I have worked with in my fifteen years at McKinsey & Company. He produces beacons of creative innovation and is generous with sharing the details to ensure quality is improved across teams and functions. He has contributed to internal communications, diversity and inclusion videos that are featured in the top ten most viewed articles for the firm, and client-focused videos that support new client work. His work and his team management are terrific, but even more impressive is his ability to maximize value by inspiring a client team to utilize media more strategically to scale their outputs and grow their influence. He is an expert in knowing how best to communicate to his audience and inspire them to action with his storytelling and video production.‚Äù

LinkedIn User ‚ÄúOsato is an exceptional Senior Video Production Expert. He goes above and beyond to produce high-quality storytelling while capturing the hearts and minds of his audience to meet business objectives. He produces a variety of artistic styles while keeping the core message of the production in focus and driving interest to the heart of the audience, clients and sponsors. He connects well with colleagues at every level, from Junior Associates to Senior Partners with the same passion, attention to detail and professionalism. At McKinsey, he has produced a great variety of work: 3D animations, live-action testimonials, documentary-style interviews, impactful inclusivity and diversity series to name a few. His viewership is in the millions. He is a pleasure to work with, and while you expect the best, he manages to exceed your expectations with every project. Osato also leads his production staff with a leadership mentality. Each team member owns their effort and gives their best work collaboratively. His work is incredibly impressive and encourages other creative professionals to aspire to deliver with the same innovative vigor.‚Äù

basic_info.search_snippet: Associate General Counsel at McKinsey & Company ¬∑ I am an experienced lawyer who takes a ‚Äúwhole brain‚Äù approach to solve complex legal problems.

detailed_profile.name: Brian Kint
detailed_profile.position: Associate General Counsel at McKinsey & Company
detailed_profile.about: I am an experienced lawyer who takes a ‚Äúwhole brain‚Äù approach to solve complex legal problems. On one side, I am infinitely curious. I love to figure out how things work. And not necessarily machines or other physical objects, but things like money laundering, feudalism, static electricity, and the Rule 5 draft. I wasn‚Äôt necessarily the kid who took everything apart growing up, but I was certainly the kid who often fell asleep with a stack of encyclopedias beside the bed. The ‚Äúrelated articles‚Äù section always led to another trip to the bookshelf. Wikipedia makes this a much lighter lift these days. On the other side, I am highly analytical and practical. I love breaking down a problem, argument, or goal its component parts then figuring out which of those parts truly matter and which are just noise. I also have a passion for numbers, and spreadsheets are a guilty pleasure of mine. I find it strangely gratifying to create a tricked-out spreadsheet and watch the cascading change in values when one cell is updated. This total brain approach has served me well in my legal career. Truly solving a legal problem requires not only that you analyze the law, but also that you do a deep dive into the surrounding circumstances, such as the client‚Äôs industry and business goals. You must frame the problem, and therefore the solution, in the context of those circumstances and goals. The most brilliant solution is worthless if it is not practical and executable. Few legal questions have a single definitive answer. Rather, the answer is what is right for a particular client, given the balance of business goals and potential risk. On the personal side, I grew up in a small town with a local dirt track, which led to a life-long love of auto racing and other forms of live entertainment, especially sports and music. There is nothing quick like the collective response to a clutch home run or an epic performance. I also enjoy playing video games and the piano. I‚Äôm not terribly good at either, but I don‚Äôt let a lack of talent get in the way of doing something I enjoy!

detailed_profile.about: I took at leap of faith and moved to Clearwater, FL. I love the water and the sunshine and am enjoying every minute of it. I am looking forward to exploring bike trails in the area and finding quiet spots to kayak. I am an HR Generalist with 2+ years of HR experience, most recently for Survival Systems USA in Connecticut. I love helping people by answering their questions or working with them through an issue they may be having. I also enjoy working with data and would like to become more involved with HRIS systems so that I could combine my HR experience with my IT background. I have enjoyed Project Coordinator or Data Analyst positions in the past. My project management experience has been an asset for all of the positions I have held as it has enabled me to organize my work as well as work with people at all levels within a company. My love of reading and learning have also been big contributors to my sucess in all of the positions I have held in the past because once I decide to take on a position, I read everything I can find to learn as much as I can. I am a fast learner and love to learn new things by jumping in with both feet.

recommendations: LinkedIn User ‚ÄúIn all my career, few co-workers have impressed me as much as Ryan Kelly. In our time working together, I saw him take over a very intricate department, lead two critical teams in a Product Owner capacity, and work across several vendors and sister brands to deliver the data our company needed, all while serving as a liaison to the organization, successfully conveying the very complex work that our teams do. Few can balance being both a fearless leader and an incredibly kind and encouraging one, working with team members daily to make sure they are empowered to deliver and that their voices were heard. Ryan was a great partner in delivering on our roadmaps and was an all-around joy to work with. I could not recommend someone more. ‚Äù

Koushik Biswas ‚ÄúRyan struck me as a passionate hands-on Technology Leader excelling in aligning and motivating his team into delivering results. His technical depth helps establish a common lingo with architects and engineers, earning their respect and accelerating delivery. His crisp communication and stakeholder management skills have cleared many hurdles for me and my team. Ryan's willingness to roll up the sleeves and lead by example is well-complemented by his strategic focus. I have seen him exercise context over control more easily than many other leaders, trusting and empowering the right people to remove blockers and gain velocity without compromising quality. I would love to work with him again!‚Äù

detailed_profile.name: Katy Mclaughlin
detailed_profile.position: Executive Editor at McKinsey & Company
detailed_profile.about: I'm an Executive Editor at McKinsey & Company. I am the editor for our Real Estate practice and am also the deputy editor of the McKinsey Quarterly. Prior to joining McKinsey, I was a reporter at The Wall Street Journal for many years. I wrote about the food and real estate industries, as well as about personal finance, mortgages, mental health, and technology. While covering the food and restaurant industries, I won two James Beard awards for excellence in newspaper reporting; as a real estate reporter, I won the National Association of Real Estate Editors Gold award.

positions.subtitle: Wall Street Journal
positions.description: Covered residential real estate and wrote the "Jumbo Jungle" column, a deep dive into mortgages. In addition to investigative pieces, I reported the annual "Buyers Guide" and "Sellers Guide" features. Contributed to and sometimes oversaw Private Properties, a competitive real estate news column.

positions.subtitle: The Wall Street Journal
positions.description: Staff reporter for Personal Journal, at the time a new section at the Wall Street Journal that covered our traditional topics from the angle of the consumer. Appeared frequently live on CNBC to discuss my stories. Worked with a team of journalistic legends including Edward Felsenthal (now editor in chief at Time), Eben Shapiro (his deputy), Jane Spencer (US Guardian editor), Jesse Pesta (New York Times editor of whatever he wants), and other geniuses including Ron Lieber and Hilary Stout (NYT). Most fun I ever had while essentially being forced to sleep under my desk.

publications.description: Women in the Workplace 2017 is a comprehensive study of the state of women in corporate America. This research is part of a long-term partnership between LeanIn.Org and McKinsey & Company to give organizations the information they need to promote women‚Äôs leadership and foster gender equality.This year 222 companies employing more than 12 million people shared their pipeline data and completed a survey of HR practices. In addition, more than 70,000 employees completed a survey designed to explore their experiences regarding gender, opportunity, career, and work-life issues. To our knowledge, this makes Women in the Workplace the largest study of its kind.

experience.title: Solutions Architect
experience.description: Worked on ATLAS, the in store point of sale system for all TMX Finance brand title pawn loans.  Originally hired on as a senior developer, my responsibilities grew to include Solution Architect, SQL Migration Architect, Business Analyst, Technical Lead, and Technical Project Manager.ATLAS was an MVC.Net web application, built on top of the CQRS design pattern, implemented with nServiceBus.  Database access was accomplished via nHibernate, with the mappings done via FluentNHibernate.  Dependency Injection was accomplished via StructureMap.Additionally, I created the SQL engine to determine $5M in monthly employee bonus payouts.  I also provided business with the Excel front end in lieu of a traditional user interface.
experience.description_html:
Worked on ATLAS, the in store point of sale system for all TMX Finance brand title pawn loans. Originally hired on as a senior developer, my responsibilities grew to include Solution Architect, SQL Migration Architect, Business Analyst, Technical Lead, and Technical Project Manager.

ATLAS was an MVC.Net web application, built on top of the CQRS design pattern, implemented with nServiceBus. Database access was accomplished via nHibernate, with the mappings done via FluentNHibernate. Dependency Injection was accomplished via StructureMap.

Additionally, I created the SQL engine to determine $5M in monthly employee bonus payouts. I also provided business with the Excel front end in lieu of a traditional user interface.

experience.title: Senior Consultant
experience.description: Worked on LCIs back office web application for managing the work flow of red light tickets.  This ASP.Net web application utilized the CSLA.Net framework to interact with a SQL Server 2005 Database.   I also architected a business to business solution for delivering ticket information to multiple municipalities.  Utilizing principles of Object Oriented Design and Design Patterns, I was able to create an abstract pattern that all municipalities would use, even though each municipality had different requirements for record structure and transport mechanism.
experience.description_html:
Worked on LCIs back office web application for managing the work flow of red light tickets. This ASP.Net web application utilized the CSLA.Net framework to interact with a SQL Server 2005 Database.

I also architected a business to business solution for delivering ticket information to multiple municipalities. Utilizing principles of Object Oriented Design and Design Patterns, I was able to create an abstract pattern that all municipalities would use, even though each municipality had different requirements for record structure and transport mechanism.

experience.title: Senior Vice President
experience.description: Ockham Research was an independent equity research provider, with an institutional client base and a significant web presence.  Utilizing SEO techniques, www.OckhamResearch.com was consistently one of the top search results for investors seeking independent financial advice on the internet.  I was on a team of 2 developers, and together we built out the MVC.Net website, the Razor Wire news service, and the dynamic generation of PDF reports for consumption by our institutional clients.  We utilized a SQL Server 2005 database with data access via the open source SubSonic ORM.  RazorWire consumed closed captioned TV feeds from business television channels and captured soundbite sized text pertaining to specific equities and included those captures on each equities page on OckhamResearch.

Ockham Research was an independent equity research provider, with an institutional client base and a significant web presence. Utilizing SEO techniques, www.OckhamResearch.com was consistently one of the top search results for investors seeking independent financial advice on the internet.

I was on a team of 2 developers, and together we built out the MVC.Net website, the Razor Wire news service, and the dynamic generation of PDF reports for consumption by our institutional clients. RazorWire consumed closed captioned TV feeds from business television channels and captured soundbite sized text pertaining to specific equities and included those captures on each equities page on OckhamResearch.

experience.title: Engineering Team Lead
experience.description: Lead the team that built out www.Rentals.com.  During my tenure, Rentals was an ASP.Net website serving up apartment and house rental listings stored in an Endeca backend server.  An Oracle database was also used to store customer data.I also built out a web service layer to sit on top of the existing www.RentClicks.com backend.  This allowed www.Rentals.Com to sell new listings on their website and have those sales processed entirely by the existing back end www.RentClicks.com infrastructure.
experience.description_html:
Lead the team that built out www.Rentals.com. During my tenure, Rentals was an ASP.Net website serving up apartment and house rental listings stored in an Endeca backend server. An Oracle database was also used to store customer data.

I also built out a web service layer to sit on top of the existing www.RentClicks.com backend. This allowed www.Rentals.Com to sell new listings on their website and have those sales processed entirely by the existing back end www.RentClicks.com infrastructure.

patents.title: Specially programmed computer server serving pages offering commercial opportunities for merchants through coordinated offsite marketing
patents.description: An e-commerce outsourcing system and method provides hosts with transparent, context-sensitive e-commerce supported pages. The look and feel of a target host is captured for future use. The host is provided with one or more links for inclusion within a page on the host website that correlates with a selected commerce object, which may be contextually related to material in the page. The commerce object can be a product, a product category, or a dynamic selection indicator. Upon activation of the provided link, a visitor computer is served with a page with the look and feel of the host website and with content based upon the associated commerce object. Where the commerce object is a dynamic selection indicator, the content is selected at the time of activation based upon an analysis of the page containing the activated link.

recommendations: Ruben Derderian ‚ÄúIt is my distinct pleasure to recommend Wenyi (Wendy) Zhu. I have known Wendy and have enjoyed her friendship and support for almost two years. In my role as Director of International Acceleration at the Houston Technology Center (HTC), I work with a number of organizations in China and have benefited greatly from Wendy‚Äôs counsel and support. I have engaged Wendy in several complex business proposals to Chinese organizations and have solicited her involvement and support in many meetings and presentations. Her knowledge of the Chinese language, thought process, and culture and her ability to explain them to me in an understandable way has been a great asset. She has a high energy level coupled with a calming and engaging manor and quickly gains the respect and confidence of everyone she meets. Her thought process is very analytical and logical which helps her quickly grasp complex concepts and she has the ability explain they in a very non-technical understandable manor. One of my responsibilities at HTC is that of creating the curriculum for and teaching the basics of entrepreneurship to new HTC client companies. Wendy is always eager to learn and has volunteered her time and support to assist whenever she can. Because of her eagerness to learn more about the principles of business and how to help new businesses get started on the right path she studied the curriculum and volunteered to mentor several of HTC‚Äôs start-up companies. Although her educational focus and background are technical, she has an uncanny ability to understand the concepts of business and express them in a straight forward and clear manner. Many of HTC‚Äôs start-up companies have benefited from her mentoring and counsel. Wendy has the energy, ambition, and ability to succeed and she will be a great asset to any organization she becomes associated with. Ruben Derderian ‚Äù

recommendations: Amanda Russell, MBA ‚ÄúSome people talk about changing the game,,,,or the world,.,then there are those who go out there and do it -Greg is one of those people. Greg's brilliance makes him an automatic leader, but it's his humility, integrity, ability to constantly think bigger, go beyond the status quo, to push the boundaries and innovate that makes him an absolute legend. Greg isn't just a friend and colleague, he has become a trusted advisor, mentor and the first person I find myself seeking advice from when it comes to business and my career in academia. Greg, your generosity with your time, your mind, and resources inspire me to reach a little higher, and I am so honored to call you a colleague and friend.‚Äù

Alan Catello Grazioso ‚ÄúGreg is an inspiring instructor and colleague. I was a grad student in his Digital Media and Advertising Strategy course at Harvard (MGMT E-6650) in 2019 and the experience was hands, practical, engaging and awe-inspiring. His strategic advice and real-world questions and insights have changed how I see online media and marketing. Greg's willingness to have 1:1 conversations and mentor students makes him stand out as a favorite faculty member among students. I consider Greg a trusted advisor and I foresee ample future collaboration opportunities. Therefore, I highly recommend that you collaborate with Greg (or take one of his classes).‚Äù

basic_info.name: Tiago Moura - Specialist chez McKinsey & Company
basic_info.search_snippet: Specialist chez McKinsey & Company ¬∑ While my passion has always been to help others, my personal and professional goals can be boiled down to a simple ...

detailed_profile.name: Tiago Moura
detailed_profile.position: Specialist chez McKinsey & Company
detailed_profile.about: While my passion has always been to help others, my personal and professional goals can be boiled down to a simple mission: to extend the impact of caring individuals. I have realised that, while there's a lot I can do to serve others, I can more sustainably and meaningfully effect change by leveraging my skills and knowledge to increase the ease in which a large group of people can care for a community. I've always been attracted to healthcare. I started my windy path to healthcare with my high school volunteer days at a local hospital, found myself working as an emergency medical respondent in college, and explored my interest in the clinical field through my degree in chemistry. Though I decided that my passion was not in direct care or research, I held to my desire to positively influence the lives of others. Over the past few years, I've been immersed in the realm of transforming primary care through my work at One Medical Group. I'm honoured to be able to continue to assist in driving forward the company's mission to deliver high quality care affordably. From my role directly interacting with patients through my growth into operational design and execution, I have had the joy of being able to watch the impact this organisation has on thousands of lives every day through patient-centred primary care powered by technology.

publications.title: Taking the first steps toward net-zero emissions
publications.subtitle: McKinsey Global Institute
publications.description: The path to net-zero emissions is full of challenges. Leadership must understand the risks and commit to change now‚Äîor face an even thornier transition down the road.

publications.title: The net-zero transition: What it would cost, what it could bring
publications.subtitle: McKinsey & Company
publications.description: Governments and companies worldwide are pledging to achieve net-zero emissions of greenhouse gases. What would it take to fulfill that ambition? In a new report, we look at the economic transformation that a transition to net-zero emissions would entail‚Äîa transformation that would affect all countries and all sectors of the economy, either directly or indirectly. We estimate the changes in demand, capital spending, costs, and jobs, to 2050, for sectors that produce about 85 percent of overall emissions and assess economic shifts for 69 countries.

publications.title: Protecting people from a changing climate: The case for resilience
publications.subtitle: McKinsey & Company
publications.description: Our new study lays bare the potential impact of climate risks for people across the globe‚Äîand underscores the need to protect the most vulnerable and build resilience. This was a collaboration with Race to Resilience at the UN Climate Change Conference of the Parties (COP26) in Glasgow.

publications.title: Solving the net-zero equation: Nine requirements for a more orderly transition
publications.subtitle: McKinsey & Company
publications.description: Net-zero commitments are rising, but the net-zero equation is not yet solved. This can only change if nine interdependent requirements are met with singular resolve, unity, and ingenuity.

publications.title: Climate risk and response in Asia
publications.subtitle: McKinsey Global Institute
publications.description: In many ways, Asia is on the frontline of a changing climate. We analyze the extent of climate risk facing the region and effective responses for adaptation and mitigation.

publications.title: Don‚Äôt Let the Pandemic Set Back Gender Equality
publications.subtitle: Harvard Business Review
publications.description: A new McKinsey analysis shows that women‚Äôs jobs are 1.8 times more vulnerable during the coronavirus pandemic than men‚Äôs jobs: Women make up 39% of global employment but account for 54% of overall job losses as of May 2020. At the same time, they bear the burden of unpaid health and child care. This setback follows a five-year period in which tangible progress toward equality in work and society stagnated. Policy makers and business leaders need to act fast to push for greater gender equality, and CEOs can start with three immediate actions.

publications.title: Globalization in transition: The future of trade and value chains
publications.subtitle: McKinsey Global Institute
publications.description: Global value chains are being reshaped by rising demand and new industry capabilities in the developing world as well as a wave of new technologies. Even with trade tensions and tariffs dominating the headlines, important structural changes in the nature of globalization have gone largely unnoticed. In Globalization in transition: The future of trade and value chains, the McKinsey Global Institute analyzes the dynamics of global value chains and finds structural shifts that have been hiding in plain sight.

publications.title: Climate change hits the poor hardest. Here's how to protect them
publications.subtitle: World Economic Forum
publications.description: Climate change is already affecting the planet, increasing the likelihood or intensity of events like floods, heatwaves, and drought, and inflicting billions of dollars worth of damage. But climate change will not affect everyone equally.

publications.title: Getting tangible about intangibles: The future of growth and productivity
publications.subtitle: McKinsey Global Institute
publications.description: A close look at how companies can make the most of intangible investments.

publications.title: Mobility‚Äôs net-zero transition: A look at opportunities and risks
publications.subtitle: McKinsey & Company
publications.description: A transition to net-zero emissions would entail much greater demand for electric vehicles. McKinsey analysis shows how the shift could create opportunities and risks for automakers around the world.

recommendations: Aleksa Nikolic ‚ÄúI had a pleasure to work with Cole while he was Global VP Operations at AIESEC. He is a great coach on strategy and team leadership, being able to always ask the right question and structure the problem in logical and leanest way possible. Cole has an impressive ability to pass a complex key message in simple and appealing manner, which was crucial for driving growth in service line he was managing. As a part of the conference team Cole was leading, I can say that he is a great leader and facilitator as he did a great job of getting the team on the same page and keeping the enthusiasm and focus in the team. He is also a great conversation buddy, being very purposeful and possessing an immense intellectual capacity and curiosity. I enjoyed working with Cole and would be glad to work with him again. I have no doubt that he would be a great contribution to any team, and would strongly recommend him.‚Äù

detailed_profile.name: Pam Keller
detailed_profile.position: Client Capabilities Specialist at McKinsey & Company
detailed_profile.about: My purpose and intentions are to combine my God-given gifts of teaching, organization, encouragement, faith, writing, editing and leadership in a useful and productive way in a corporate environment. My current job at McKinsey & Company allows me to put all of my skills to work in a global environment, which is very exciting. Teaching piano is a one-on-one relationship that I thoroughly enjoy, and I have the privilege of passing along my years of musical experience while using my skills in teaching, although I maintain a very small number of students. My work at the Bradenton Executive Center centered on my writing, editing and teaching skills, and I had the privilege of working in a Godly environment with a team of women who shared my desire to overlap business and ministry and serve others. My editing/writing jobs were a creative outlet for me and I thoroughly enjoyed taking someone else's material and making it shine with professionalism, cohesiveness and eloquence--I now do that at McKinsey!. My greatest joy, however, was my own company--Simplify. This company gave me the opportunity to coach, teach, and organize others while encouraging them. It is a passion of mine to teach others how to efficiently run their home or office, and I loved the freedoms that result for each client from the fruit of our work together. I enjoyed my last few years with my own company and the variety and flexibility that it provided; but I am thoroughly enjoying the corporate environment these days and the unique challenges that this brings to my table.

experience.title: Piano Teacher
experience.description: Teaching piano was more of a hobby than a job.  I have taught every age from 5 to 72 over my 20+ years of teaching.  I loved combining my God-given gifts of teaching and encouragement to guide my students through the disciplines of learning the piano.  I always developed a solid friendship with my students and we had a great time together.  I focused on theory and the basics and foundations of piano, including exercises and scales.  It was an absolute joy to spend 30 minutes with each student every week, and we had a great time as we committed to the journey of piano-playing together as a team. I wouldn't be surprised if I returned to it at some point in the future!

experience.title: Professional Consultant in Writing/Editing
experience.description: I began freelance editing & writing in the summer of 2013 after unearthing these dormant skills in the winter of 2013 in my part-time work at the Bradenton Executive Center.  I had written 2 manuals and several website bios as well as edited countless contracts, documents, correspondence, and marketing material.  This re-awakened in me the desire to have my own proofreading service, and I  began some side consulting in this area.  I have edited a friend's e-book for publication, have reviewed policies and procedures documents as well as several websites, and have created an interactive table of contents.  I enjoyed the process of taking a document that is well-written by someone who knows their subject, but doesn't know how to present it professionally.  I also enjoyed organizing words, sentences and paragraphs into a semblance of order and coherence.  For those business people who can't put words on paper, I enjoyed the process of gathering information and creating/writing a comprehensive document for them.  Overall, I simply like to both write and edit, in almost any form.  My vision for this particular branch of my self-employment was to offer the opportunity to other businesses to look and sound professional through my own contributions of cleaning up and scrubbing all documents, correspondence and online presence materials.  I believe that my education in marketing/business, my experience in office management and executive assistance, and my writing/editing abilities created a robust niche that allowed me to be able to offer a valuable service to businesses that struggled with a professional presence.

experience.title: Owner
experience.description: Simplify provided organizational services for both home and office.  In the home environment, I organized for my clients in several ways--I was hired to come in for a decluttering job of any size, to coach a client in how to efficiently run their home and maintain their space [everything from calendar control to decluttering to controling the paperwork/mail to menu planning and shopping, etc.], or I was hired on a maintenance basis to regularly come to a client's home and maintain the efficiencies of the home operations. In the office environment, the same process applied, but was tailored to an office's needs.  Because of my background in office management and procedures, I can streamline a business' paperwork and communications, organize supplies, create spreadsheets for any necessary tracking or metrics, create templates or manuals or any documents needed, and organize an e-file system.  I was hired on a one-time basis to get things in order, or on a maintenance basis, where I came to the client's office weekly for a few hours to maintain efficiencies.

volunteer_experience.info: I taught a small group at my church called Simplify from 2007 through 2014. It ran for 14 weeks [7 meetings, every other week] every spring and every fall. The purpose of the group was to teach women how to manage the resources and time that God has given them in a manner that is pleasing to Him and that creates efficiencies and freedoms. The classes covered the philosophy of getting organized, setting our priorities, avoiding procrastination, persevering, goalsetting, managing paperwork‚Ä¶ Show more I taught a small group at my church called Simplify from 2007 through 2014. It ran for 14 weeks [7 meetings, every other week] every spring and every fall. The purpose of the group was to teach women how to manage the resources and time that God has given them in a manner that is pleasing to Him and that creates efficiencies and freedoms. The classes covered the philosophy of getting organized, setting our priorities, avoiding procrastination, persevering, goalsetting, managing paperwork, controlling our calendars, decluttering our spaces, managing our cleaning schedules, menu planning, organizing recipes, creating effective to-do lists, creating efficient grocery lists, maintaining efficient kitchen spaces, and organizing our holiday planning. Every subject finds its foundation in Biblical values and we started and ended each session with a devotional and prayer. Our ultimate goal was to find time each day to spend with God so that He can give us the wisdom and strength to organize the rest of our time and spaces. I provided the tools to get the practical side of life organized and running smoothly. My end goal was always to encourage the class members to pursue God, and as Proverbs 9:10 says, He will make the hours of our day more productive and the years of our life more fruitful. Show less

publications.title: America 2021: The opportunity to advance racial equity
publications.subtitle: McKinsey & Company
publications.description: Repairing the frayed social fabric in the United States is one of the most pressing issues of our time. It‚Äôs not a new problem. But if we do not address the underlying issues preventing us from achieving equitable growth and inclusion, the economic and social divisions that drove the civil unrest following the murder of George Floyd in May 2020 will only become worse. The new administration has an opportunity to make a forceful case for racial equity by explaining the challenges, highlighting the areas of opportunity, and taking bold action to embed racial equity into our national fabric.

publications.title: It‚Äôs time for a new approach to racial equity
publications.subtitle: McKinsey & Company
publications.description: Despite decades of efforts by public-, private-, and social-sector organizations, racial inequity has only increased. Can a concerted, coordinated effort reverse this trend?

publications.title: Building supportive ecosystems for Black-owned US businesses
publications.subtitle: McKinsey & Company
publications.description: The right business ecosystems can mitigate or negate the effects of structural obstacles to business building for Black business owners‚Äîand add $290 billion in business equity.

publications.title: Blog: What will it take to build ore black-owned businesses? McKinsey & Company, 15 October 2020
publications.subtitle: McKinsey & Company
publications.description: Black families in the U.S. possess about a tenth of the wealth white families do. If that wealth gap were closed, $1 to $1.5 trillion in economic output could be created. I believe increasing Black business ownership would play a role in wealth creation and closing the gap.

publications.title: COVID-19: Investing in black lives and livelihoods, McKinsey & Company, 14 April 2020
publications.subtitle: McKinsey & Company
publications.description: Amid the rising deaths, infections, and possible economic implosion of the COVID-19 pandemic, the most pressing need in the United States is to save lives and arrest any plunge into a prolonged recession or depression. The crisis is already hitting major social and economic systems, yet black Americans will experience a disproportionate share of the disruption‚Äîfrom morbidity and mortality to unemployment and bankruptcy.

publications.title: The case of accelerating financial inclusion in black communities, McKinsey & Company, 25 February 2020
publications.subtitle: McKinsey & Company
publications.description: A lack of financial inclusion for black Americans exists at every level of the financial system. Understanding the sources of exclusion is the first step to fixing the system.

publications.title: The future of work in black America
publications.subtitle: McKinsey & Company
publications.description: Research shows that automation trends may be widening the racial wealth gap. This article reveals possible interventions that may help African American workers prepare for the future.

publications.title: The economic impact of closing the racial wealth gap
publications.subtitle: McKinsey & Company
publications.description: The persistent racial wealth gap in the United States is a burden on Black Americans as well as the overall economy. New research quantifies the impact of closing the gap and identifies key sources of this socioeconomic inequity.

publications.title: Automation and the future of the African American workforce
publications.subtitle: McKinsey & Company
publications.description: Without concerted effort, automation could heighten disparities that already harm minority workers. The kinds of support activities performed by service workers, administrative-support workers, operatives, laborers, and helpers are, not surprisingly, more easily automated than are the directive activities performed by executives, professionals, technicians, and sales and craft workers. And that leaves African Americans especially vulnerable.

publications.title: Blog: New research highlights gap between race and earning power in the US: Meet the authors
publications.subtitle: McKinsey & Company, 22 October 2018
publications.description: McKinsey recently released the results of our first-time research about the earning potential of black families in the United States. The findings were presented to 200 prominent leaders at the first Black Economic Forum (BEF) in late summer. We served as the knowledge partner for the event, hosted by the Executive Leadership Council and Beta Iota Boul√©, both of which work to advance black leadership. Shelley Stewart and Jason Wright, McKinsey partners, co-led the initiative.

publications.title: Estimating Individual Promotional Campaign Impacts through Bayesian Inference
publications.subtitle: Journal of Consumer Marketing
publications.description: The purpose of this paper is to estimate individual promotional campaign impacts through Bayesian inference. Conventional statistics have worked well for analyzing the impact of direct marketing promotions on purchase behavior. However, many modern marketing programs must drive multiple purchase objectives, requiring more precise arbitration between multiple offers and collection of more data with which to differentiate individuals. This often results in datasets that are highly dimensional, yet also sparse, straining the power of statistical methods to properly estimate the effect of promotional treatments. The findings of this work focus on comparing a machine-learned Bayesian approach with linear regression (which is representative of the current state of practice among industry practitioners) in the analysis of a promotional campaign across three key areas: highly dimensional data, sparse data and likelihood matching. The original contribution is the application of machine-learning to Bayesian Belief Network construction in the context of analyzing a multi-channel promotional campaign‚Äôs impact on individual customers.

patents.title: Missile launch system and apparatus
patents.description: A missile is guided and/or supported within a canister by a collapsible support structure. In one embodiment the collapsible support structure is part of a railcar, which includes a missile-engaging guidance and/or support structure, a rail engaging element, and a hinged pantograph-like collapsible support extending between the missile-engaging structure and the rail engaging element. A hinge of the pantograph is locked in a storage state and during part of motion during the missile launch. The hinge is unlocked, and travel of the rail engaging element is stopped. The missile-engaging support structure momentarily continues its motion, and the pantograph collapses. Capture elements engage parts of the railcar or the canister during collapse to prevent rebound of the missile-engaging support structure toward the missile.

detailed_profile.name: Terrence Hackett
detailed_profile.position: McKinsey & Company - Associate Director - Learning Design
detailed_profile.about: I have a deep background in learning, design, development and delivery. At McKinsey, I create learning solutions for our 10,000 client service professionals around the globe. My specific focus is on mid-tenure professionals - including engagement managers and associate principals. I have a passion for teaching and classroom facilitation. I have designed and developed dozens of live classroom simulation and have worked extensively in digital learning solutions. Prior to McKinsey, I was a senior manager with Deloitte serving the company's 9,000 Tax professionals in the U.S. I have a master's degree in education from Harvard University with a special focus on technology and learning. Prior to corporate learning, my experience included designing and developing software programs for elementary and middle schools. I have owned and operated my own learning consulting practice. I also have a strong background in writing, communications and change management.

publications.title: A future that works: Automation, employment, and productivity
publications.subtitle: McKinsey Global Institute
publications.description: Advances in robotics, artificial intelligence, and machine learning are ushering in a new age of automation, as machines match or outperform human performance in a range of work activities, including ones requiring cognitive capabilities. In this report, part of our ongoing research into the future of work, we analyze the automation potential of the global economy, the factors that will determine the pace and extent of workplace adoption, and the economic impact associated with its potential.

publications.title: How to win in the age of analytics
publications.subtitle: McKinsey Quarterly
publications.description: Since the concept took hold, big data has made big waves. The field of analytics has developed rapidly since the McKinsey Global Institute (MGI) released its landmark 2011 report, Big data: The next frontier for innovation, competition, and productivity. But much value remains on the table as organizations wrestle with issues of strategy and implementation. In this episode of the McKinsey Podcast, MGI partner Michael Chui and McKinsey senior partner Nicolaus Henke speak with McKinsey Publishing‚Äôs Simon London about the changing landscape for data and analytics, opportunities in industries from retail to healthcare, and implications for workers.

publications.title: The age of analytics: Competing in a data-driven world
publications.subtitle: McKinsey Global Institute
publications.description: Is big data all hype? To the contrary: earlier research may have given only a partial view of the ultimate impact. This report suggests that the range of applications and opportunities has grown and will continue to expand. Given rapid technological advances, the question for companies now is how to integrate new capabilities into their operations and strategies‚Äîand position themselves in a world where analytics can upend entire industries.

publications.title: Where machines could replace humans‚Äîand where they can‚Äôt (yet)
publications.subtitle: McKinsey Quarterly
publications.description: In this article, we examine the technical feasibility, using currently demonstrated technologies, of automating three groups of occupational activities: those that are highly susceptible, less susceptible, and least susceptible to automation. Within each category, we discuss the sectors and occupations where robots and other machines are most‚Äîand least‚Äîlikely to serve as substitutes in activities humans currently perform. Toward the end of this article, we discuss how evolving technologies, such as natural-language generation, could change the outlook, as well as some implications for senior executives who lead increasingly automated enterprises.

publications.title: The growing potential of quantum computing
publications.subtitle: McKinsey Global Institute
publications.description: The CEO of D-Wave Systems, Vern Brownell, explains how quantum computers are poised to solve important problems in industries ranging from financial services to medicine. In this interview with McKinsey‚Äôs Michael Chui, Brownell discusses what quantum computing is, how it works, and where it‚Äôs headed in the next five years.

publications.title: How Many of Your Daily Tasks Could Be Automated?
publications.subtitle: Harvard Business Review
publications.description: At McKinsey, we are conducting research into the impact of automation on jobs and organizations and recently published a brief paper previewing some of our findings. The most important insight has been that it is far more useful to think about the activities that can be automated rather than entire occupations‚Äîhanding over discrete bits to machines, like pulling out the most useful data from an analyst‚Äôs report, generating a report on the latest sales figures, or moving products around a warehouse.

publications.title: Four fundamentals of workplace automation
publications.subtitle: McKinsey Quarterly
publications.description: What will be the impact of automation efforts, multiplied many times across different sectors of the economy? Can we look forward to vast improvements in productivity, freedom from boring work, and improved quality of life? Should we fear threats to jobs, disruptions to organizations, and strains on the social fabric? We launched research to explore these questions and investigate the potential that automation technologies hold for jobs, organizations, and the future of work.

publications.title: An executive‚Äôs guide to the Internet of Things
publications.subtitle: McKinsey Quarterly
publications.description: As the Internet of Things (IoT) has gained popular attention in the five years since we first published on the topic, it has also beguiled executives. In what follows, we identify three sets of opportunities: expanding pools of value in global B2B markets, new levers of operational excellence, and possibilities for innovative business models. In parallel, executives will need to deal with three sets of challenges: organizational misalignment, technological interoperability and analytics hurdles, and heightened cybersecurity risks.

publications.title: The Internet of Things: Five critical questions
publications.subtitle: McKinsey Global Institute
publications.description: In these short videos, McKinsey‚Äôs Michael Chui poses five critical questions about its development to experts ranging from MIT Media Lab director Joi Ito to Google‚Äôs Advanced Technology and Projects group deputy director Dan Kaufman to Cloudera cofounder and chief strategy officer Mike Olson to O‚ÄôReilly Media founder and chief executive officer Tim O‚ÄôReilly. An extended and edited transcript of their comments follows.

publications.title: The Internet of Things: Mapping the value beyond the hype
publications.subtitle: McKinsey Global Institute
publications.description: The Internet of Things‚Äîdigitizing the physical world‚Äîhas received enormous attention. In this research, the McKinsey Global Institute set out to look beyond the hype to understand exactly how IoT technology can create real economic value. Our central finding is that the hype may actually understate the full potential of the Internet of Things‚Äîbut that capturing the maximum benefits will require an understanding of where real value can be created and successfully addressing a set of systems issues, including interoperability.
